content.body: TabAtkins_, actually, Hixie filed it for me (as I noticed after posting to www-style)
Ah, heh.
Well, as long as it's filed, I'm happy.
heh youtube seems to be out to give <video> a boost by switching to hopelessly broken buffering behavior
now it won't buffer more than 30 seconds ahead, which means i ... can't watch things
(unless i feel like watching it in 30 second chunks)
you can't watch online?
it won't stream fast enough to watch it
normally i'd just pause it and let it buffer to full in the background ... but now it stops buffering after the buffer is 30s ahead of the play position, which broke that
it doesn't buffer fast enough even if it's playing?
wow, the html5 player is doing it too (capping the buffer); wonder if that's something they're doing in script (can you even do that?) or if FF is doing the same thing
i would assume it's the server
oh wait, the html5 one kept buffering (eventually)
(the flash one stops after 30s read-ahead and stays stopped indefinitely)
(the html5 one working is what I expected--i suppose you could probably jump the hoops to cripple prebuffering like that with <video> if you wanted to badly enough, though)
has anybody written tests for CSS animations?
finds http://test.csswg.org/source/contributors/microsoft/incoming/CSS3/animations/
lol @ XHTML 1.0 Strict
Yes, could do that once every day.
border-collapse with colspan/rowspan is "funny" ... http://dabblet.com/gist/3082417 (compare webkit and gecko)
firefox 16 will be the unprefixing release, huh?
Yeah
SimonSapin: opera has a third rendering :-)
looks for other things to unprefix
zcorpan: yes, I just checked
SimonSapin: what's correct per spec? does it say?
the spec doesn’t say anything …
zcorpan, Ha. Ha. Ha.
I’ll just do whatever is more convenient in WeasyPrint
anyone have ie to check?
i bet it has its own take on it
I don’t even what to bother reporting this to www-style, nothing’s gonna happen until someone makes css3-tables in a few decades
would be nice to have issues documented somewhere though when that someone wants to take it
maybe a wiki page is better than emails to www-style
I think that CSSWG has both a wiki and a bugzilla for tracking issues
heycam|away: shouldn't webidl drop the "must have a length" if ES already requires length to be present?
SimonSapin, and Tracker
Ms2ger: indeed
Might be useful to ask MikeSmith to create a bugzilla component for tabkes
tables*
Ms2ger: wrote about this to www-style, I’ll leave the rest to the WG
Ms2ger: CSS tables?
btw, I added a bunch of CSS features to http://platform.html5.org/
lots more green flags there now
i love how http://html5please.com/#WebSockets recommends disabling websocket for safari but at the same time using Flash Sockets
Is there really no Array.remove() or something in JS?
arr.splice(i, 1) seems a bit abstruse compared to arr.remove(i) or such.
CSS Undefined Module
Do you mean CSS 2.1?
yeah :)
what's the procedure of publishing a Final Specification?
Sacrifice a goat
declare the spec dead?
i thought it was possible to publish Final Specifications several times
i thought that was just Final Fantasy
I think that's the idea
Maybe AryehGregor knows
Yes, that's my understanding.
A Final Specification is a frozen snapshot.
But a CG can publish however many it wants.
And/or continue work on the specs after forking them.
I imagine the procedure for publishing a Final Specification is "Talk to Ian Jacobs, he'll be very excited because no one's done it yet".
should whatcg publish FSs for all the drafts (and one for html)?
i see whatcg doesn't list html under current drafts
but i thought the purpose was to publish html as FS at some point
The purpose was the patent policy
And I thought that happened earlier than FS
well we haven't published a draft either so i guess the CLA doesn't apply for html yet
i haven't read the CLA and FSA in detail yet
http://www.w3.org/community/reports/reqs/ copyright boilerplate for FS says to link to https://www.w3.org/community/about/agreements/fsa/ but that redirects to fsa-deed, i guess final/ was intended
also uses https on some links but they seem to redirect to http
sends an email
fast ij is fast
Ms2ger, the patent policy before FS only applies to contributors, I think.  At FS, everyone is invited to agree to license their patents on the subject matter, although it's optional.  (I think.)
I guess I should publish a FS of the editing spec.
But if the WHATCG wants to test the waters first, please be my guest.  :)
annevk: re: HTTP & data URLs & same-origin: http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/xhr/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#data:-urls-and-http seems to allow it
annevk: couldn’t find it in the HTML spec
annevk: or did I misunderstand that section ^?
hey everyone, I have a question about the XHR2
is Anne here?
that's an easy question, nope
hehe
ok, I'll try again later then, thanks
Anne's on vacation, except when he checks in.
ahh
hmm, I'll just drop this in to boil now then
it looks to me like the current spec doesn't have any support for streaming, am I correct? has this been discussed?

the thing is, we're building these JS audio decoders and *not* streaming would be horrible UX as potential use cases can include 1h+ songs and even for 3m+ songs downloading the whole song before starting playback is usually unacceptable
so for now, we're using partial requests, but that's hogging bandwidth like a... well, hog.
I was wondering if there's a better solution cooking and whether we could maybe contribute ideas
iirc you can access arraybuffer while loading to get the data so far (never tried it/don't know if it's implemented/might be wrong)
don't think that lets you actually stream (eg. discard data as you read to read an unbounded stream)
zewt: ok, I'll try that and see if it would be good enough, thanks!
i don't suppose we can just drop xslt support from the platform?
I'm cool with this.
stares at hsivonen's scary-looking feedback regarding how readyState should work with xslt
oh hey, i already have a section that basically says "i give up on xslt, but in the absence of xslt defining this stuff, here's some handwaving suggestions"
adds more to it
gar does google really not index w3 tickets
site:https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/ 1 result
view-source:https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/robots.txt
So, no.
(obviously, the real question was "why does w3's tracker have a completely BS robots.txt")
that's beyond absurd ... even for the w3c
jwalden: __proto__ is in Carakan!
yay!
zewt: bugzilla in general disables robots because of load, iirc
also the real robots.txt that matters is https://www.w3.org/robots.txt
They should learn it some caching :-)
(a robots.txt in a subdirectory doesn't work)
Do some varnish magic.
which spec should I be looking at to get the list of all possible color names?
css3-color
SVG? CSS2.1? CSS3 Color module?
http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-iccprof
but it's from 2001 :/
http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-color/ is a REC from last year
cool, thanks
jarek: If you want to use the list for something, I have a few versions of the list in JSON.
TabAtkins_: I need a list of all color names that could be used with "fill" SVG property
TabAtkins_: how many colors are on your list? 147?
In browsers, 'fill' takes every single CSS color, including ones that SVG doesn't officially define.
All of which are defined in css3-color, that gsnedders linked to.
TabAtkins_: css3-color seems to contains exactly the same colors as SVG 1.1
Yes.
The colors haven't changed for a decade.
there is gray and gray which are basically the same color :/
I mean gray and grey
Yes, they're identical.  The named colors list is *retarded*.
I assume that decision to include both gray and grey on the list was purely political?
probably dates back to X11
I didn't know that X11 was designed by a committee
it looks more like addition from W3C
Totally backwards compatible, most of it never used.
Not political. The X11 list was copied from an old rgb.txt file that someone had.
Someone on that Linux distro decided that that particular list was worthwhile.
I respectfully submit that that distro maintainer was stupid.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X11_color_names suggests it's even more complicated than i feared
looks like netscape was on the path of blame
"Some browsers like Netscape navigator insisted on an ‘a’ in any ‘Gray’ except for ‘Light Grey’."
I this mess starts in the 19th century :P
http://grammarist.com/spelling/gray-grey/
There's 50 Shades of Grey, but only 1 Shade of Gray.
It's that time of year again when I post in some WBS surveys and see if anyone cares enough to fill them out.
Specifically, https://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-200-objection-poll/ and https://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-189-objection-poll/

were there two threads about that same topic? could have sworn I replied to this already
must have been a discard
